Option A. Flumazenil: Incorrect because flumazenil is the antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning.

 

Option C. Atropine: Incorrect as atropine is used for organophosphate and other cholinergic poisonings.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Incorrect because naloxone is the antidote for opioid poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension in the context of alcohol consumption from a local shop strongly suggest methanol poisoning. The appropriate treatment is ethyl alcohol, which competes with methanol for metabolism and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites.

 

Table for Treatment of Methanol and Ethylene Glycol Poisoning

choices.text: Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.
﻿﻿﻿Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.text: Which of the following is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate

 

“Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased is false. 

 

This process occurs in the TCA (Krebs) cycle and is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, a mitochondrial enzyme.


In advanced liver disease, alpha-ketoglutarate is diverted toward glutamate and glutamine synthesis (to help detoxify ammonia), which decreases its availability for the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate is true. In liver disease, there is an increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate as a way to detoxify ammonia. 

 

Option C. Decreased ATP synthesis is true. in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine. This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia is true. In advanced liver disease, the liver's ability to detoxify ammonia is compromised, leading to elevated ammonia levels in the bloodstream, resulting in hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Detoxification of ammonia takes place in the liver, where it is metabolised and excreted as urea (urea cycle). Due to impairment of ammonia metabolism in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine.

 

 

This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

questions.text: True about Warburg effect?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation

 

This is the correct statement. The Warburg effect is characterized by cancer cells utilizing glycolysis even in the presence of oxygen (aerobic glycolysis), leading to the production of lactate. This metabolic shift is a hallmark of many cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Makes cancer cells immortal: This statement is not true. The Warburg effect is a metabolic phenomenon observed in many cancer cells where they preferentially use glycolysis to generate energy, but it does not make cancer cells immortal. Immortality of cancer cells is typically associated with mutations that allow them to evade normal cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.

 

Option C. Produce more ATP: This statement is not true in the context of the Warburg effect. While glycolysis is less efficient at producing ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation (which occurs in the mitochondria), cancer cells under the Warburg effect primarily generate ATP through glycolysis, which is less efficient but provides other metabolic advantages to rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Option D. Decrease glucose uptake: This statement is not true. Cancer cells under the Warburg effect often increase their glucose uptake to meet their high energy demands through glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warburg effect

 

  • This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O2. This is known as aerobic glycolysis.
  • Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs, hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).

 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 738

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3’ UTR

 

  • This is the correct option.
  • miRNA binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA, leading to translational repression or mRNA degradation, thereby regulating gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5’ UTR (Untranslated Region):

  • This region is not typically the binding site for miRNA on mRNA.
  • miRNA primarily binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA to regulate gene expression.

 

Option C. Gene Promoter:

  • Gene promoters are regions involved in transcription initiation, not the binding sites for miRNA.

 

Option D.  Gene Body:

  • miRNA primarily targets the 3' UTR of mRNA, not the gene body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The binding site of miRNA on mRNA is typically the 3’ UTR (Untranslated Region), where miRNA can regulate gene expression by binding and influencing mRNA stability or translation.

 

Ref - Lehninger 6th e/p 1081

choices.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.text: The WHO-created slogan 'Perform Correctly,' regarding initial snake bite assistance, includes everything listed below except for which one? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Incisions

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound (incisions, suction, rubbing, tattooing, vigorous cleaning, massage, application of herbs or chemicals, cryotherapy, cautery) as this may introduce infection, increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding.

 

First Aid treatment outside the hospital setting has very limited role in snake bite management. The first aid treatment can be divided in three categories:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Reassurance: Many snake bites are caused by non-venomous snakes. And even after most venomous snake bites, the patient can be saved the risk of death is not immediate. If the patient gets panicked his heart rate would increase which in term would spread the venom rapidly.

 

Option B) Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite: Detailed history will be helpful to know the type of snake Detailed history in snakebite is essential to delineate treatment options moving forward. Information to obtain includes the timing and location of bite, the onset of any symptoms, and any first aid administered in field. Take a past medical history with detail to which medications they are on, especially anti-platelet / anti-coagulant medications, and any allergies that would prohibit from receiving antivenom.

 

Option C) Go to hospital: Main treatment of snake bite can be given in hospital only (Anti-snake venom, airway maintenance, fluids etc.)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound. Always reassure the patient, immobilize the limb, and seek medical help immediately without attempting harmful interventions like making incisions or applying chemicals.

questions.text: Fluoroacetate is a component of pesticides. Which of the following metabolic pathways is inhibited by this compound? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TCA cycle

 

Sodium fluoroacetate, is usually used as a rodenticide. It is highly toxic towards humans and other mammals through inhibition of the enzyme aconitase in the tricarboxylic acid cycle (metabolic uncoupler), caused by 'lethal synthesis' of an isomer of fluorocitrate (FC). FA is found in a range of plant species and their ingestion can cause the death of ruminant animals.

 

Inhibition of the TCA Cycle by Fluoroacetate:

  • Aconitase: Converts citrate to aconitate.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate is metabolized to fluorocitrate, which inhibits aconitase, leading to the accumulation of citrate and disruption of the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolytic pathway:

  • Function: Converts glucose to pyruvate, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not affect glycolysis.

 

Option C. Oxidative phosphorylation:

  • Function: Produces ATP through the electron transport chain and ATP synthase.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option D. ETC (Electron Transport Chain):

  • Function: Transfers electrons from NADH and FADH2 to oxygen, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of TCA Cycle

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds are cholinesterase inhibitors and cause cholinergic symptoms like bradycardia, hypotension, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome). They do not cause hypertension.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning typically leads to gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), jaundice, hepatic and renal failure. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning can cause a range of symptoms including gastrointestinal distress, peripheral neuropathy, skin changes (rain drop pigmentation), Mees' lines on nails, and long-term effects like cancer. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Restlessness
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status

questions.text: According to wound ballistics, A gunshot wound showing burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound, can be classified as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close shot entry wound

 

Burning (heat of the gases), blackening (deposition of soot) and tattooing (unburned powder particles embedding into the skin) are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds do not show burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are usually larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They show a clean entry hole.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Exit wounds from distant shots also do not show these features and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

choices.text: Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation
It is associated with a case of electrical burns

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the image given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

 

The above image shows postmortem change of marbling.

 

Marbling:

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic colour change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of colour change in putrefaction:
    1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
    2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black colour.
  3. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  4. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  5. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen within 24 hours of death: While marbling starts within 24 hours, it becomes more prominent at around 36–48 hours.

 

Option C. Due to aseptic nonbacterial cause: Marbling is a result of bacterial activity and the decomposition process, not aseptic causes.

 

Option D. It is associated with a case of electrical burns: Marbling is not associated with electrical burns; it is a postmortem change due to putrefaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling, a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black lines on the skin, is due to the accumulation and formation of sulph-meth-hemoglobin during putrefaction.

questions.text: SARS CoV-2 diagnosis is done by all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southern blotting

 

  • Southern blotting is not a standard method for SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis. It is a technique primarily used for the detection and analysis of DNA fragments, not RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2. 
  • Diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) primarily involves detecting viral RNA or immune response markers. Let's break down the options:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR) —Used

  • Gold standard for detecting viral RNA.
  • RNA is reverse-transcribed to DNA, then amplified.
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
     

 

Option B. Real-Time PCR —Used

  • Often used in combination with RT (i.e., RT-qPCR).
  • Provides quantitative data and real-time amplification curves.

 

Option C. Southern Blotting —Not used

  • Southern blotting is used to detect DNA, not RNA.
  • It is not suitable for viral RNA detection.

 

Option D. Immunoassays — Used

  • Used for antibody detection (IgM, IgG) or antigen detection.
  • Examples: ELISA, lateral flow assays (like rapid tests).
  • Useful for screening, epidemiological surveillance, and past infection confirmation.
     

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arsenic

 

The given clinical scenario points towards arsenic poisoning

 

Causes of arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning occurs most often in major areas of agriculture and industrialization. It occurs through contaminated groundwater, air, soil or food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium permanganate: Typically causes caustic injuries, including severe mucosal burns upon ingestion, but not the full range of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Thallium: Causes symptoms such as gastrointestinal distress, neurological symptoms, and hair loss, but does not match the full clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning causes anemia, abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and kidney damage, but does not match the described symptoms of conjunctivitis and burning sensation in the throat and stomach.

 

Educational Objective:
